en: For the Dinos Painter, a pot-painter associated of the Kleophon Painter, see M. Mendonca, The Dinos Painter, (Dissertation, Oxford, 1990). This krater was attributed by Aaron J. Paul. Genital depilation was practiced by women in ancient Athens, particularly by hetairai (prostitutes). Aristophanes more than once alludes to the practice of singeing pubic hairs, and a few red-figure vases show women using a lamp for this purpose; e.g. Mississippi 1977.3.112 (ARV2, 331, 20). For a thorough discussion of the subject, with ancient sources and illustrations of related vase-paintings, see Kilmer 1982. In no other example is Eros present, and the fact that he is actually doing the singeing suggests that the purpose is erotic enhancement rather than hygiene. Aaron Paul notes the close similarity between the woman being depilated and the sculptural type known perhaps erroneously as the Venus Genetrix; see A. Paul, "Eros and a Depilation Scene by the Dinos Painter," (paper abstract) AJA 97 (1993). It is perhaps unlikely that Aphrodite would be represented completely naked in this period, and even less likely that she would be depicted undergoing this procedure. The Venus Genetrix type, however, is based on a Greek sculpture of just this period, and it may be that the pose selected for this hetaira was inspired by a sculpture of Aphrodite seen by the Dinos Painter. That she and her companion are in fact prostitutes is suggested not only by the depilation, but also, as Paul points out, by the combination of nudity and the wearing of thigh-bands and crossed cords between the breasts, a combination also affected by dancing girls; eg. London E 203; ARV2, 1131, 164. On a kylix in the Fondazione Mormino, Palermo, a seated nude woman points toward her own genitals while Eros leans on her shoulder, also pointing toward them, as though offering instruction (no lamp is depicted); V. Tusa, Odeon, ed altri monumenti archeologici (Palermo 1971) 361, no. 41, pl. 14d. For Eros in close contact with a nude woman wearing crossed cords on her chest, cf. a cup fragment in the University of Jena; as on this vase, the woman is more likely a hetaira than Aphrodite (ARV2, 1511, 11).
Unbroken; minor flaking and abrasion; hard incrustation on the handles, rim, lower body, and foot.

A. J. Paul, "Eros and a Depilation Scene by the Dinos Painter," (paper abstract) AJA 97 (1993); M.I. Davies, "Merkins and Modes," Images et Socit en Grce ancienne (Lausanne 1984, publ. 1987) = Cahiers d'archologie romande 36 (1987) 243-8.
Sackler Museum files; AIA paper by A. Paul.
